IN THE CROWN COURT AT BIRMINGHAM  
R v. Mr H  
Case No. B2025/19823  
Sentencing Remarks – His Honour Judge R. M. Fairclough  
Filed: 2 October 2025

Mr H appears before this court for sentence on two counts: engaging in conduct in preparation for acts of terrorism contrary to section 5(1)(a) of the Terrorism Act 2006, and possession of an article for a purpose connected with the commission of terrorism contrary to section 57 of the Terrorism Act 2000. The conduct in question spanned from December 2022 through to the defendant's arrest on 15 February 2025.

The defendant was first taken into custody at 07:15 on the morning of that date following a coordinated operation by Counter Terrorism Policing West Midlands (CTPWM), supported by specialist officers from the National Counter-Terrorism Policing Headquarters and cyber forensic experts seconded from the Central Cyber Crime Unit. The arrest was the outcome of an extensive investigation initiated after a tip-off from an international intelligence-sharing arrangement. Warrants were executed at the defendant’s flat in Aston, Birmingham, under section 43B of the Terrorism Act 2000. At the time of arrest, officers seized a laptop computer, several encrypted external hard drives, assorted electronic components, and a quantity of chemical substances stored in containers labelled with innocuous workshop terms.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_1}

This investigation, codenamed Operation Ironvale, combined traditional surveillance, undercover operatives, and digital forensic analysis over a period of approximately 14 months. The investigatory techniques involved decrypting secure messaging platforms, correlating device logs with third-party service metadata, and monitoring travel records. The complexity of the operation occasioned significant demands on policing resources at a time when counter-terrorism units nationwide faced unprecedented operational pressures. Such pressures are well-documented in the accepted annual reports from the National Counter Terrorism Policing Network, noting that staffing shortages, recruitment challenges, and case backlogs have become persistent features since the 2021 financial year.

It is not without interest, if not direct relevance, to mention that during the investigative period, the National Firearms Licensing Unit reported a surge in the number of applications for airsoft rifles and realistic firearms replicas ranging from 2019 through 2024. While no link to Mr H was found in this context, the trend represents an important background milieu within which individuals with violent extremism proclivities may acquire expertise or paraphernalia disguised within common hobbies.

A procedural matter merits brief emphasis. The case experienced multiple adjournments, not uncommon in counter-terrorism trials; the complexities of security-cleared disclosure, the logistics of arranging closed material procedures, and the late production of expert technical evidence necessitated extensions beyond initial listing dates. This court is also aware from the hearing bundle that the Legal Aid Agency’s administrative systems in this instance encountered challenges in promptly authorising additional hours for the defence’s cyber forensic expert. Such delays, regrettably frequent in this jurisdiction, place an unnecessary strain upon defendants’ rights to fair representation and, by extension, upon the overarching public confidence in the justice system.

The journey from remand to trial spanned over 18 months. During this period, Mr H was granted bail on one occasion subject to stringent electronic monitoring and residence conditions, but this was revoked following a breach involving contact with an individual subject to a separate terrorism-related prohibition order. The breach was reported to the Multi-Agency Public Protection Arrangements (MAPPA), category 3, which convened to consider the increased risk posed and reinforced supervision measures accordingly. The MAPPA meeting minutes, included in the case papers, record some disagreement among participating agencies regarding the calibration of ongoing risk; while police representatives favoured a robust approach, probation and mental health professionals counseled a measured response emphasizing therapeutic engagement.

At the plea and trial preparation hearing held on 19 July 2025, Mr H indicated a not guilty plea, maintaining the position until the close of the prosecution case on 17 September 2025. The trial spanned 12 days in Court 5 of this Crown Court, heard by a jury of twelve. Following deliberation, the jury returned unanimous verdicts of guilty on both counts. The defendant later changed his plea to guilty in respect of a further charge of possessing a prohibited weapon, which was added during the course of proceedings but not proceeded with at trial. The application for a Newton hearing on this ancillary count was withdrawn on the morning of sentence.

It is, regrettably, not unusual in terrorism cases to observe a deferral of guilty pleas until the strength of the evidence compels admission. As this court has previously noted—albeit in different contexts—the timing of a plea bears directly upon the quantum of credit to be afforded. In R v. Siddiqui [2021] EWCA Crim 1223, the Court of Appeal elucidated that early guilty pleas are accompanied by the dual benefits of expediting proceedings and demonstrating genuine remorse, thereby justifying significant mitigation. Conversely, pleas entered only at the precipice of conviction warrant markedly reduced credit. The observations in Siddiqui are consonant with similar dicta enshrined in R v. Westbrook [2019] EWCA Crim 642, where the court underscored the consequences of procedural gaming on court resources and witness welfare.

It is of ancillary note that the defendant’s co-defendant, Mr J, remains at large and is the subject of an active European Arrest Warrant. Mr J faces separate proceedings in absentia. The failure of Mr J to appear has occasioned extended delays in this court and has drawn commentary from senior members of the judiciary regarding the challenges of parallel prosecutions involving multiple defendants dispersed internationally. While Mr J’s conduct is undoubtedly relevant to the broader operation, this court must focus its attention squarely upon the culpability and circumstances of Mr H alone.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_2}

The Crown’s case included voluminous electronic evidence retrieved from encrypted Discord servers and anonymised financial transactions flagged by the Financial Intelligence Unit. A specialist officer from the West Midlands Regional Cyber Crime Unit provided detailed witness evidence concerning the extraction and analysis of data from these sources. The testimonies described advanced obfuscation techniques used by the defendant, including multi-hop relay routing and ephemeral chat deletion protocols, complicating the forensic task. The prosecution established, through expert testimony, that the defendant had assembled chemical precursors potentially capable of explosive synthesis, corroborated by contemporaneous digital notes sketched in cipher.

At trial, the defence contended that the chemical substances were intended solely for benign artistic purposes, citing the defendant’s amateur interest in botanical dye extraction. While the court accepts that hobbyists frequently engage with hazardous materials, the contextualisation against encrypted evidence, travel to sites known for extremist activity, and possession of weaponry tips the balance firmly toward guilty intent.

A historical reflection is warranted regarding the legislative framework. The 2006 Terrorism Act was introduced to redress identified gaps in the law concerning preparatory acts, which had previously limited prosecution where actual attack executions were absent. The Act’s section 5 offence reflects Parliament’s intent to arrest and penalise those whose conduct demonstrates a clear posture toward terroristic planning, even if ultimate violence is prevented through law enforcement interventions. This echoes earlier cases such as R v. O’Brien and others [2001] UKHL 34, where the House of Lords contemplated the proportionality of restraining nascent but dangerous conspiracies.

Of interest, though not directly connected to the present defendant, is the decision in R v. Powers [2022] EWCA Crim 671, involving a defendant convicted for smuggling quantities of Class A drugs concealed within agricultural machinery. The court’s sentencing remarks in Powers elaborated on the significance of cross-border organised crime and the evolving nexus between narcotics trafficking and extremism funding—a tangential but increasingly salient subject within counter-terrorism policing circles.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_3}

The defendant maintained a covert online presence under several pseudonymous accounts. Linguistic experts produced assessments highlighting recurring phrases and stylistic consistencies with doctrinal materials disseminated by proscribed organisations. This evidence lent weight to the Crown’s submission that Mr H was knowledgably engaged and deliberately directing his efforts toward incitement and facilitation of terrorist acts.

In the course of forensic investigation, officers also uncovered a series of encrypted audio files containing monologues and dialogues referencing past attacks and ideological exhortations. These were juxtaposed with training notes on battlefield engagement posted on similar platforms. The cumulative effect of this material corroborated the Crown’s argument regarding intent and capacity.

It must be observed, however, that the defendant’s digital footprint included items unrelated to proscribed activity, such as a sizeable catalogue of photographs of historic automotive engineering projects and personal family celebrations. Defence counsel made extensive reference to these as evidence of a multifaceted individual, not reducible to his extremist persona. While such facets of character are relevant to assessment, they do not detract from the seriousness of the offending conduct.

In considering the material recovered, the court takes judicial notice of the proliferation of social media channels that simultaneously host benign hobbyist content and extremist propaganda, an intersection that challenges contemporary legal boundaries and evidentiary practices. This phenomenon was referenced in the report by Professor Caroline Lawton, whose 2024 treatise “Networks of Influence: Social Media and Radicalisation Dynamics” has influenced recent policy deliberations.

The defendant’s possession of materials linked to digital encryption raises further issues about the evolution of criminal methodologies in the information age. It is illustrative that investigations into Operation Sabreclaw – unrelated save by thematic subject matter – uncovered remarkably similar encryption tools utilized by organised criminal enterprises, albeit for drug trafficking rather than terrorism. This overlap suggests a shared toolkit among different modalities of serious crime.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_4}

A vocational component to the defendant’s profile merits mention. Prior to the outbreak of offending, Mr H was employed for two years as a junior technician at Midlands Engineering Solutions. His line manager characterized him as “reliable and precise” but noted concerns regarding his disengagement following increasing social isolation and expressed ideological frustrations. This observation dovetails with findings in the pre-sentence psychiatric report by Consultant Forensic Psychiatrist Dr Naima Bukhari, who noted signs consistent with “early-onset depressive features and social withdrawal” but no formal diagnosis of psychosis or personality disorder.

Dr Bukhari further remarked on the defendant’s “rigid cognitive framework” and limited emotional flexibility, suggesting these factors compounded susceptibility to ideological rigidity. The report underlines the importance of intensive psychological interventions; nevertheless, it warns that compliance remains uncertain given the defendant’s prior sporadic engagement with voluntary support agencies.

The probation service report highlights obstacles faced by supervising officers: inadequate staffing levels, high caseloads, and difficulties coordinating multi-disciplinary input within the context of existing resource constraints. The local Host Town Mental Health Trust is currently managing an undersupply of forensic psychology staff, resulting in extended waiting times for specialist assessment—a systemic challenge recognised across the National Health Service and addressed only tentatively in recent policy white papers.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_5}

Travel history forms a salient part of the prosecution evidence. The defendant’s movements included a 10-day visit to Riga in October 2023, ostensibly for tourism, but intelligence obtained post-flight reveals contacts with individuals known to the European Counter Terrorism Network. CCTV footage in Riga’s Old Town shows Mr H departing a café at the same time as a Latvian national later convicted for trafficking firearms to extremist groups. Despite defence assertions of coincidence, these links formed part of an intricate web of circumstantial evidence.

The defence noted that Mr H also traveled to Cornwall in July 2022 and Gloucestershire in summer 2023 with family, events confirmed by benign social media posts and photographs, which counsel cited to illustrate normal social engagement. While these activities indeed reflect an aspect of normalcy, they neither negate nor dilute the serious nature of the offences before this court.

Further abrasions to the court’s calendar were occasioned by delays stemming from industrial disputes affecting court staff, notably clerical personnel responsible for case listing. These strikes—although outside the control of judicial authorities—have had ripple effects on effective criminal justice management nationally. Additionally, an unforeseen partial refurbishment of this court building in May 2025 caused a temporary relocation of some hearings to satellite venues located some miles away, disrupting routine practice.

It is germane to mention that the West Midlands Police Dog Unit recently reported an uptick in incidents involving weapons detection at public transport nodes, including Exeter Station, where a riot shield was found abandoned in 2024 following disturbances unrelated to this case. Such events, while not connected to Mr H, exemplify the broader environment within which counter-terrorism operations function daily.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_6}

Analysis by financial investigators revealed a series of cryptocurrency transactions amounting to £4,150 exchanged from wallets associated with Mr H to addresses linked, per intelligence databases, with black-market suppliers of dual-use chemical precursors. These payments were processed via MixerX, an obfuscator network notorious for enabling illicit fund laundering.

Criminal exploitation of decentralised finance platforms, while constituting a small minority among users, remains a significant enabler for both transnational organised crime and terrorist financing. The court notes the observations in the Home Office’s 2024 report “Crypto and the New Frontier of Financial Crime,” which outlines the persistent challenges law enforcement face in tracking and disrupting these flows.

The forensic effort required to parse blockchain transactions is monumental, often necessitating international liaison and protracted analytic timeframes. Much of this work is carried out by stretched Cyber Crime Units operating under resource restrictions visibly compounded over the prior five years.

The defendant’s digital camouflage strategies included the use of sophisticated VPNs routed through countries with restrictive data sharing policies, complicating investigative penetration. This is illustrative of an arms race between criminal innovators and enforcement authorities. One should note, without passing judgement, that balancing privacy rights and public safety in this domain remains an ongoing legislative and ethical debate.

Surveillance footage establishing the defendant’s presence adjacent to a known explosive materials containment site on the Coventry Canal towpath on 4 June 2024 was corroborated by independent timestamped mobile geolocation data recovered from his dormant phone. Reconstruction of this element of conduct was laborious, as it required cross-referencing multiple data sources, including records from the National Waterways Authority and GPS logs made available by the defendant’s brief mobile provider, Veridian Telecom.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_7}

Turning to the defendant’s background, Mr H is 30 years old and hails from a working-class family in Birmingham. His educational trajectory revealed no early signs of academic difficulty; he completed A-Level studies in mathematics and physics with commendable grades. His brief spell at the local university ended prematurely in 2019 after withdrawal citing “personal reasons,” a phrase commonly redacted in institutional documentation.

Family correspondences submitted to the court include a letter from Ms Zahra H, the defendant’s mother, describing Mr H as “a kind-hearted but often troubled son,” who had become increasingly withdrawn in the years prior to arrest. Statements from a local youth club where Mr H once volunteered attest to his intermittently positive engagements with young people, underscoring a dichotomy in character that complicates simplistic narratives.

Such human complexities highlight the multidimensional nature of defendants in terrorism-related cases. It is a point consistently made by academics and practitioners alike that the digital façade may mask undercurrents of psychological distress, social dislocation, and ideological vulnerability.

Within the prison environment, Mr H is reported to have had a mixed record. There were no recorded adjudications for violence or disciplinary breaches. However, reports from chaplaincy and mental health nursing staff suggest limited participation in rehabilitation programmes, corresponding with his noted scepticism of institutional authority.

The court recognizes the efforts of custodial staff and contracted psychological support workers who strive tirelessly under challenging conditions—often beset by overcrowding, understaffing, and budgetary constraints—to encourage rehabilitative engagement. The genuine commitment of such public servants merits acknowledgment.

{INSERT_FACT_SNIPPET_8}

The forensic psychiatric report authored by Dr Umar Mistry presents a comprehensive clinical picture. Dr Mistry identifies traits consistent with high-functioning autism spectrum disorder, characterised by difficulties in social communication and a preference for routine and predictability. Although no major mental illness is diagnosed, the report highlights the defendant’s elevated risk of persistent ideological fixation absent robust, tailored intervention.

The risk assessment utilises Structured Professional Judgment (SPJ) methodologies, incorporating historical, clinical, and risk management factors. The conclusion is guarded: Mr H poses a high risk of serious harm related to extremist beliefs with potential recidivism in post-sentence contexts if unsupported by intensive risk management.

The report recommends a blended approach to rehabilitation incorporating the Desistance and Disengagement Programme (DDP), extended licence supervision, and electronic monitoring. The court is mindful that while such programmes offer pathways toward reintegration, they are neither universally successful nor lightning rods for easy resolution.

It must also be acknowledged that the defendant’s case has drawn correspondence from the Birmingham Council of Mosques, expressing concern about potential impacts on community cohesion and highlighting the need for sensitivity in sentencing. While those concerns are moral and sociological in nature, this court remains bound by legal principle and the paramount obligation to safeguard the public.

In conclusion, the offences before the court represent a grave breach of the peace, undertaken with a degree of sophistication and planning meriting a sentence commensurate with the highest culpability. Mitigating factors, including the defendant’s remoteness of prior offending and intellectual attributes, carry limited weight in the context of premeditated terrorist conduct.

The court orders the preparation of a detailed pre-sentence report, including contributions from probation, forensic psychology, and relevant counter-terrorism multi-agency groups. This report should address the viability of custodial and community-based components, propose appropriate licence conditions, and consider the feasibility of ongoing surveillance and electronic restrictions.

These sentencing remarks are issued this day, 2 October 2025, in Court 6 at Birmingham Crown Court. They have been transcribed and recorded in accordance with Part 5 of the Criminal Procedure Rules. The formal record of conviction and sentence will be transmitted to the appropriate authorities within statutory timeframes.

These are the orders of the court.
